title-group.article-title: Closed midshaft clavicle fractures: An evidence-based triage management algorithm.

abstract.title: Abstract:
Introduction:
abstract.p: The management of MidshaftMid-shaft clavicle fractures (MSCF) has evolved over the last 3 decades. Controversy exists over which specific fracture patterns to treat and when. This review aims to synthesise the literature in order to formulate an appropriate management algorithm for these injuries in both adolescents and adults.
abstract.title: Methods:
abstract.p: This is a systematic review of clinical studies comparing the outcomes of operative and non-operativenonoperative treatments for MSCFs in the past 15 years. The literature was searched using, PubMed, Google scholar, OVID Medline and Embase. All databases were searched with identical search terms: MidshaftMid-shaft Clavicle fractures (±Fixation) (±nonoperative-operative).
abstract.title: Results:
abstract.p: Using the search criteria identified, 247 studies were deemed eligible. Following initial screening, 220 studies were excluded on the basis that they were duplicates and/or irrelevant to the research question being posed. 27 full text articles remained and were included in the final review. The majority of the meta-analyses draw the same conclusions which are that operatively treated fractures have lower non-union and malunion rates but that, in those fractures which unite (either operative or non-operativenonoperative) the functional outcomes are the same at 6 months.
abstract.title: Discussion:
abstract.p: With regards to the adolescent population, the existing body of evidence is insufficient to support the use of routine operative management. With regards to adult fractures, the key to identifying patients who benefit from operative management lies in the identification of risk factors for non-union. We present an algorithm which can be used to guide both the patient and the surgeon in a joint decision-making process, in order to optimiseoptimize patient satisfaction and outcomes.

meta-value.named-content: R51 Please provide an in-text citation for reference .

body.title: Introduction:
body.p: The clavicle is an elongated S-shaped bone, horizontally placed between the sternum and the acromion of the scapula and overlying the superior part of the ribcage. Clavicle fractures account for 5 to 10% of all adult fractures1 . Seventy to eighty percent are in the middle third as classified by Allman.2 .

The management of MidshaftMid-shaft clavicle fractures (MSCF) has evolved over the last 3 decades.3,4 . The publication of a prospective multicentre randomisedrandomized control trial in 2006 by the Canadian Orthopaedic Trauma Society4 led to a shift in practice in certain centres.3. The absolute indications for surgery remain unchanged: open fractures, clavicle fractures associated with a floating shoulder and those associated with neurovascular compromise, requiring immediate exploration. Beyond these indications there is controversy over which specific fracture patterns to treat and when.5-8.

In the UK, clavicle fractures may not be treated by a specialist trauma or upper limb surgeon in the setting of a general fracture clinic. The current literature can be difficult to interpret leading to potential variation in treatment. The authors have witnessed both over and under treatment, unnecessary follow upfollow-up and inconsistent management with unnecessary imaging. Patients with these fractures require clear and specific plans, based both on their personal needs, physiology and the fracture morphology.

This review aims to synthesise the literature in order to formulate an appropriate management algorithm for these injuries in both adolescents and adults. We present an algorithm which can be used to guide both the patient and the surgeon in a joint decision-making process, in order to optimiseoptimize patient satisfaction and outcomes. The review is intended to provide structure and guidance for the treating surgeon but should not take the place of clear clinical judgement.
body.title: Methods:
-Eligibility critgibility Criteria:
body.p: All papers comparing the outcomes of operative and non-operativenonoperative treatments for MSCFs in the past 15 years where included.
body.title: Information sourion Sources
body.p: The literature was searched between 2006 and 2021 using, PubMed, Google scholar, OVID Medline and Embase
All databases were searched with identical search terms:
MidshaftMid-shaft Clavicle fractures (±Fixation) (±nonoperative-operative).
body.title: -Study seley Selection:
body.p: Studies identified by the electronic search were screened initially by title and abstract to exclude any topics unrelated to the question posed by the study.

The focus of this review was to assess the evidence base of operative and non-operativenonoperative treatment lines of MSCFs. As such, General review articles and papers focusing on financial outcomes were excluded. Additionally, studies comparing management options of lateral and medial thirds fractures of clavicle were excluded.
After the initial screen the remaining abstracts were scrutinized and any duplicate articles were extracted.
The remaining articles were included in the systematic review. Articles were assessed by 2 independent reviewers and any differences in article inclusion were discussed and resolved by consensus.
body.title: -Data collection pra Collection process:
body.p: There were multiple standardized outcome measures in the studies identified. Constant-Murley score (CS), Disabilities of Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score, duration of follow upfollow-up and outcome measures where appropriate were used in each study and their results were identified.
body.title: -Risk of biaisk of Bias:
body.p: As the majority of studies were papers showing success or feasibility of surgeries, we acknowledge that there will be a degree of reporting bias, given that published articles are more likely to publish positive results and data collection was heterogeneous.
body.title: -Results:
body.p: Using the search criteria identified, 247 studies were deemed eligible. Following initial screening, 220 studies were excluded on the basis that they were duplicates and/or irrelevant to the research question being posed. 27 full text articles remained and were included in the final review (Figure 1).

The papers selected consisted of a number of prospective/retrospective case series, cohort studies and systematic reviews/meta-analyses. All studies were validated using CASP (Critical Appraisal Skills ProgramProgramme) checklists. There was heterogeneity between the papers with regards to the severity of injuries, as well as the outcome measures observed.
body.title: Results:
body.p: We subdivided our results into retrospective and prospective studies, as well as randomisedrandomized control trials and meta-analyses. The results of our search are detailed in Table 1Table I.

caption.title: Studies: category, sample size and outcome

td.p: Non-operativeNonoperative and operative treatment of adolescent fractures leads to similar complication rates, satisfaction and functional outcomes

p.named-content: Comparable Return of normal shoulder function between surgical and conservative treatment when union was achieved

td.p: Early fixation of comminuted fractures leads to improved patient-oriented outcomes, improved surgeon-oriented outcomes, earlier return to function and decreased rates of non-union and malunion
Functional recovery is better in the first 6 weeks when there is fixation with anatomical plate for displaced fractures
Improvement in the rates of fracture union and functional scores with operative management
Fixation of clavicle fractures improved the union rate at 9 months
Fixation improved functional outcomes and lower rates of malunion and at one year
Improved function scores at 6 months. Improved union rates.
Surgical intervention leads to better outcomes and early functional recovery in young active adults
Duration to union is improved with fixation, with no functional difference at 6 months
Intramedullary pin fixation is the optimal treatment
Surgical treatment of MCFs significantly reduces the non-union rate and shortens the time to union
Functional outcomes and union rates were improved with fixation
No significant difference between operative and non-operativenonoperative management in young patients
Surgical treatment provides a lower rate of overall treatment failure and a better functional outcome, but is associated with more implant-related complications
No significant difference in treatment modalitiesmethods
Significant reduction in non-union and favourable early functional outcomes are associated with fixation
Fixation reduces the risk of non-union, but does not have a clinically relevant advantage regarding final functional outcome
Fixation reduced non-union, malunion and neurological complication rates of clavicle fractures

p.named-content: Operative fixation carries lower risks of non-union, with early improved functional outcomes and less disability

td.p: Time to return to sporting activity
Fixation resulted in quicker return to sporting activity
Functional outcome significantly improved in in operative group
No differences in complications or functional outcomes
Functional outcomes were equal but cosmetic result poorer in older children

body.p: There were 4 retrospective studies, 5 RandomisedRandomized controlled trials (RCTs), 6 non randomisedrandomized prospective trials, 9 meta-analyses, 1 systematic review and 2 systematic reviews of meta-analyses.

The multiple meta-analyses and systematic reviews have analysedanalyzed the merits of each of these papers. In this review we have tried to identify the “take home message” which would facilitate decision making.
body.title: Prospective studies:
body.p: There are a significant number of well-run studies which conclude that fixation provides better union rates and clinical outcomes at most time points however many also conclude that there is no significant difference in clinical outcome by 6 months post injury.

The publication of a prospective multicentre randomisedrandomized control trial in 2006 by the Canadian Orthopaedic Trauma Society4 led to a shift in practice in certain centres. The study indicated that fixation of displaced clavicle fractures resulted in improved functional outcomes and a lower rate of malunion and non-union when compared to nonoperative treatment at one year of follow-up. Subsequent prospective, multicentre trials were published supporting operative intervention.

Ahrens et al9 conducted a multicentre RCT and observed DASH score and CMS, as well as patient satisfaction, were all significantly better in the fixation group at 6 weeks and 3 months. They concluded that fixation is a safe and reliable intervention with better early functional outcomes.

Qvist at al10 published a multicentre, prospective parallel randomized controlled trial and concluded that fixation resulted in faster functional recovery and a higher rate of union. However, shoulder function remained equal after six months and at one year.

The findings of these trials were not universally reproduced. Smaller trials, such as the prospective study by Khorami et al11, found no significant changes in outcome in either group. Echalier et al12 published a non-randomised prospective study measuring CMS and DASH. These were significantly better in the surgical group from the second to the sixth week but there was no significant difference 3 and 6 months. Return to work was earlier in the surgical group.

Dhakad et al13 published a prospective study and concluded that early primary plate fixation for MSCF resulted in improved patient-oriented and surgeon-oriented outcomes along with an earlier return to function and decreased rates of non-union and mal-unionmalunion.
Naveen et al14 published a prospective study and concluded that the time to union was reduced, rate of malunion and non-union was lower, and CMS scores were higher in the surgical group.
Purushothaman et al15 observed significant improvement in the rates of fracture union and functional scores with operative management in a prospective study over 2 years.

Ban et al16 published a partially blinded prospective RCT and the observed that the number needed to treat to avoid one symptomatic non-union was 6.2. They concluded that they could not advocate for either an all-operative or an all-nonoperative approach.
Robinson et al17 conducted a prospective multicentre RCT and observed that fixation was associated with better functional outcomes.

p.span: Nicholsen et al
concluded that acute plate fixation of displaced midshaftmid-shaft
clavicular fractures was not associated with earlier return of normal shoulder function when union was achieved.

body.title: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses:
body.p: A number of large systematic reviews have been conducted. These generally conclude that surgical fixation leads to a faster return to activity, sport and employment.

p.span: Martin et al
observed that surgical fixation demonstrated a lower risk of non-union compared to
nonoperative management, resulting in significantly less disability early after surgery.

body.p: Liu et al20 concluded that operative treatment reduced the non-union, malunion and neurological complication rates of clavicle fractures, but did not affect the delayed union rate.
Hill et al21 demonstrated an earlier return to work amongstamong motivated young patients who underwent intramedullary nailing.
Wang et al22 concluded that operative fixation improved functional outcomes and union rates.

Devji et al5 demonstrated that 1 in 4 patients developed a complication regardless of the treatment modality. Functional outcomes were superior in the operative group. The authors were unable to conclude that the evidence supported routine operative fixation of displaced MSCF.
Robertson et al23 found that operative management of displaced mid-shaft fractures was found to offer improved return rates and times to sport compared to non-operativenonoperative management.

Wei Jiang et al24 compared non-operativenonoperative measures, plate, and intramedullary pin fixation in a meta-analysis. They observed that there were no differences in the effectiveness assessed by the CMS at 6 weeks, 3, 12, and 24 months and suggested that intramedullary pin fixation might be the optimal therapeutic approach.

Woltz et al25 concluded that plate fixation significantly reduced the risk of non-union, but did not have a clinically relevant advantage regarding final functional outcome. They observed that secondary operations were common after both treatments. There was not enough evidence to support routine operative treatment for all patients with a displaced midshaftmid-shaft clavicular fracture.

Ahmed et al26 concluded that a considerable reduction in non-unions, together with early functional outcomes, was encountered more with fixation. However, due to the similarity in other outcome measures, the authors concluded that there was inconsistent evidence regarding the best treatment for displaced midshaftmid-shaft clavicle fractures.

Guerra et al27 concluded that surgical treatment of MCFs significantly reduces the non-union rate and shortens the time to union as compared with the nonoperative approach and, despite a slightly higher incidence of complications, leads to better shoulder functional scores at short- and long-term follow-up.
Zhao et al28 concluded that surgical fixation provided a lower rate of overall treatment failure and a better functional outcome, but was associated with more implant-related complications.
body.title: Adolescent fractures
body.p: Five studies have looked specifically at the management of these fractures in the younger patient (adolescent). Most papers indicated that there was no benefit in surgery, except in the older paediatric cohort where the cosmetic result of surgical management was superior.

Nawar et al,29, presented a meta-analysis study of seven studies that covering 528 mid-diaphyseal clavicle fractures in patients aged 8 to 18 years. Those patients were followed up from 2 weeks to 3.7 years. The authors concluded that there was no significant difference in the time to achieve union, the time to return to activity and the overall complication rate between the operative and the non-operativenonoperative groups

Heyworth et al30 conducted a prospective randomisedrandomized control trial at eight large paediatric centres. Non operative treatment of patients in this younger cohort demonstrated lower complication rates and similar satisfaction and functional outcomes.

Prinz et al31 looked at a total of 60 displaced midshaftmid-shaft clavicle fractures in children and adolescents. All patients under the age of ten were treated conservatively and had very good functional and cosmetic results. Patients over the age of ten received either conservative treatment or fixation with a k-wire or intramedullary nailing. Functional outcome, irrespective of treatment modality was as good as in younger children, but the global and cosmetic satisfaction score was much lower. Older patients treated non-operatively suffered from more pain and were dissatisfied with the long immobilisationimmobilization. The authors recommended consideration of intramedullary fixation in this group.

Herzog et al32 conducted a retrospective study on 20 patients. The patient cohort was followed from the time of their injury for a year and a half. They reported that the amount of variability in functional outcomes for the non-operativenonoperative group suggested that some of these patients may have developed dysfunction. The authors did acknowledge that their results should be interpreted with caution as their sample size was small.

Song et al6 treated 23 adolescent patients with non-operativenonoperative management and compared them to 18 patients treated with fixation in terms of radiological, functional outcome, and complications. Non-union developed in neither group. No significant intergroup differences were observed for the occurrence of delayed union or time to union. Both operative and non-operativenonoperative groups showed satisfactory outcomes in terms of disabilities of the arm, constant shoulder scores, and shoulder and hand scores. However, recovery of shoulder range of motion was significantly faster in the operative group.
body.title: Discussion:

p.span: Non operative management of clavicle fractures was the standard in the 60
and 70
with relatively small case series by both Neer
and Allman indicating that non-union was extremely rare and that nonoperative management should be the treatment of choice.
Trends towards operative management began in the late 90
. One contributing factor may have included the introduction of locking precontoured plates,
, as these are associated with a low risk of failure and previously, fixation was achieved with dynamic compression plates.
An increasing body of evidence subsequently published,9-12,18 ,has suggested that equivalent outcomes can be achieved with non-operativenonoperative
management. Additionally Nicholson et al
concluded that routine plate fixation of displaced midshaftmid-shaft
clavicular fractures was not cost-effective. They suggested that a targeted approach to fixation of patients who are at higher risk of non-union would be more efficient.

body.p: As a consequence of the shifts in treatment trends the authors felt that a standardisedstandardized algorithm based on the current available evidence would be beneficial.
body.title: Development of a treatment algorithm
body.p: The majority of systematic reviews and meta-analyses draw the same conclusions which are that operatively treated fractures have lower non-union and malunion rates but that, in those fractures which unite (either operative or non-operativenonoperative) the functional outcomes are the same at 6 months.

p.span: The accurate identification of patient cohorts which will potentially do worse with non-operativenonoperative
management may be the key to determining which patients require surgical management. Robinson et al
noted in their prospective RCT that the improvement in function noted in the operatively managed patients was down to the increased union rate. In a previous paper, Robinson et al
determined that, gendersex
, lack of cortical apposition and comminution were all independently associated with non-union. Murray et al

identified smoking status, overall fracture displacement and comminution as independent risk factors for non-union. Murray concluded that if all fractures were treated non-operatively the number needed to treat to prevent a non-union would be 7.5. If only fractures with a predicted probability of >
were managed operatively, the number of patients managed operatively to prevent a single non-union would be reduced to 1.7.
The same group also identified the effect of delay in treatment on ultimate displacement of a fracture.
. They suggested that radiographicradiological
evaluation at 6
after injury may have superior predictive value compared with information available at the time of the injury. They indicated that the presence of a high QuickDASH score ( ≥
points), no callus on Xrayradiograph
and movement at the fracture site were all risk factors for non-union. The presence of 2 of these 3
risk factors conferred a non-union risk of 60
. With none of these present, the risk of non-union dropped to only 3
In a study published in 2021,
, Nicholson et al

reviewed the effectiveness of ultrasound at predicting union by the detection of callus formation. They concluded that the presence of bridging callus on ultrasound was associated with a union in 98.6
of patients studied.
Based on the evidence provided by Hill et al
who suggested that clavicle shortening of 2
or more was associated with non-union this measure is often cited as an indication for operative management.
This figure of 2
is controversial and has been disputed.
. Jones et al
demonstrated that standard radiographs of the clavicle were insufficient to reliably determine the degree of shortening and that surgery should not be based purely on this criterion. Thorsmark et al
also noted that existing techniques of measuring clavicular shortening had either reliability or methodological issues. Patient positioning
and delays in obtaining imaging were also found to be confounding factors.
. The solution would appear to be to use radiographs with the arm in a standardisedstandardized
position at a standardisedstandardized
period of time from injury but currently there is no consensus as to what form this should take.
The clinical picture is contradictory. In 2021
Subramanyam et al
published a prospective study of 100
with displaced fracture of the middle third of the clavicle who were treated conservatively. They concluded that for every 1
of shortening or 1-unit increase of angulation, there was a reduction in the Constant Score around 14
These findings contradicted those of a number of other studies. Goudie et al
concluded that no association existed between shortening and functional outcome or satisfaction in patients with healed displaced midshaftmid-shaft
clavicular fractures up to 1
following injury. A systematic review by Malik et al
noted a heterogeneity of imaging projections and demonstrated that there was no significant association between fracture shortening and outcome score in displaced midshaftmid-shaft
clavicle fractures managed nonoperatively. The authors concluded that routine CT imaging to enable accurate measurement with the subsequent risk of radiation exposure could not be justified due to
the increased radiation dose of a CT scan of the shoulder (2.06
). This was found to be significantly higher than that of a plain chest radiograph (0.1

Given the heterogeneity of outcome measures and imaging projections used, it is impossible to determine to what extent – if any – shortening has an effect on functional outcomes. Authors commentating that shortening may have an effect on outcomes
have themselves stipulated that the complex three-dimensional3D
configurations of fractures cannot be fully appreciated on radiographs. Therefore, without standardisationstandardization
of imaging modalitiesmethods
, functional outcomes and measurement methods the conclusion cannot be drawn that shortening is an indication for surgery.

body.p: As with all literature-based studies there is an inherent publication bias in the evidence we have reviewed and we have attempted to mitigate this as much as possible. No trauma management algorithm will be perfect and we have not attempted to make and all-encompassing protocol. The intention is to provide clinicians who may be less familiar with the management of midshaftmid-shaft clavicle fractures with an evidence-based management plan. It is up to the individual to adapt this based on the patient they have in front of them.

Based on the evidence identified, the authors propose an algorithm for the treatment of displaced midshaftmid-shaft clavicle fractures (Figure 2). This accounts for consideration of risk factors, controversies surrounding displacement and patient factors. This will allow the treating surgeon in the outpatient setting to discuss the options available based on the existing evidence and to provide a cost effectivecost-effective and balanced care plan.
body.title: In the outpatient settie Outpatient setting:

p.span: If a patient is under 18 – they should be counselled for non-operativenonoperative
management (as per Nawar et al).
If they are over 18, It should be explained to the patient that under optimal
settings (without risk factors for non-union), there is a 70
of union at 6
with 96
at 12

named-content.data-track-change: weeks37

p.span: Those who have risk factors for non-union should be offered operative intervention (Robinson et al
and Murray et al).

body.p: In the clinical setting, the role of the treating surgeon is to simplify the decision-making process for the patient. The presence or otherwise of the folllwing risk factors should be identified and explained to the patient.

p.span: If the patient is a smoker, their odds of non-union are almost four times higher
If they have a comminuted fracture their odds are almost twice as high.
If there is a lack of cortical apposition the risk of non-union is almost twice as high
If they are female, they have a slightly higher risk of non-union.
If the patient’s life circumstances dictate that they require improved functional outcomes at 6
they may be offered surgery (Echalier et al).
). In patients with highly physical jobs (eg
active military personnel or sportsmen) or those with active lifestyles, surgery can be offered to improve functional outcomes, as suggested by Lake et al.
Shortening on its own is not an indication for surgery, in line with the evidence presented by Goudie
and Malik et al.
In line with the management strategy developed by Nicholson et al,
, all patients should be reassessed at 6
for the following criteria. If they have 2 of the following three features, a QuickDASH score greater than 40, no callus on Xrayradiograph
and movement at the fracture site they should be advised that there is a 60
chance of progressing to a non-union and operative intervention should be considered. If ultrasound is available, this should be used to confirm the presence of bridging callus.

body.p: All patients being counselled for surgery should be made aware of all risk factors as well as the purpose of the surgery – which is primarily to reduce the risk of non-union and to improve acute functional outcomes. A shared decision on treatment should then be taken.
body.title: Conclusions:
body.p: With regards to the adolescent population, the existing body of evidence is insufficient to support the use of routine operative management. Although there is some evidence to support an earlier return to function,6,32 , the largest study reviewed29 indicated that there was no benefit observed with operative intervention.

With regards to adult fractures, it is difficult to interpret the apparently contradictory findings contained in the literature over the last two decades. The heterogeneity in treatment methods with both non operative (sling vs brace vs return to free movement) and operative (nail vs plate) mean that the findings above must be interpreted with care. The use of different outcome measures further complicates decision making.

The authors recommend the use of an algorithm to facilitated shared decision making between the patient and the treating surgeon in order to optimiseoptimize any treatment given to suit the unique circumstances of the patient, supported by the existing body of evidence. We would encourage treating surgeons to make use of their algorithm and feedback their experiences for further refinement of the treatment process.
